DOC.HEAD: Greek Orthodox Building Reopens in Turkey After 48-Year Dispute
DOC.TEXT: The Greek Orthodox Church celebrated Mass on Sunday in a 16th-century building that it finally restored after settling a long dispute with the Turkish government with the help of Jimmy Carter. Patriarch Dimitrios II, who led the service, said the reopening of the refurbished building, which was severely damaged by fire 48 years ago, could help improve relations between Greece and Turkey. More than 1,500 people, including representatives from 13 Eastern Orthodox churches around the world, attended the Mass at the Patriarchal Church of St. George. The celebrants included 400 people from Greece, including four government ministers and two former premiers. The ceremony was broadcast by the state-run ERT television of Greece. Turkey's tourism minister, Ilhan Akuzum, also attended. In his address, Dimitrios said he hoped the inauguration of the building would contribute to the development of peace between Greece and Turkey, which have been bitter enemies since Turkey occupied the northern part of Cyprus since 1974. Greece's state minister, Nikos Temelis, said after the ceremony that his country would work toward furthering cooperation between the two nations. A message of congratulations was sent by former President Carter, who helped obtain the Turkish government's permission to rebuild the four-story wooden structure, which houses offices and a small church. The building was gutted by fire in 1941. An adjacent building has been used as the church's offices since then. The Turkish government for years denied repeated requests for permits to rebuild, saying the Greek government had refused similar project requests by the Turkish-Moslem minority in Western Thrace. But the Greek Orthodox church was finally granted permission in 1987 after the intercession of Carter and Archbishop Iakovas of Americas during 1986 visits. Turkey, a predominantly Moslem country, is a secular state. There are 5,000 ethnic Greeks living in Istanbul, down from 100,000 when the republic was set up in 1923.
